That is why I say that it would transform a dangerous sham into a dangerous reality.
9.30 p.m.
I want to deal for a moment with the reason why I use the word "dangerous". I have always been opposed to this legislation because it seems to me to sow the seeds of future conflict. I doubt whether there is the demand for self-government in Scotland which the Scottish nationalists there and in the House say exists. I believe that what people really resent today is over-government, over-taxation and the weight of bureaucracy.
Devolution is sold, to the extent that it is sold, to the people of Scotland and Wales as a means of escaping that over-government. But in reality it will serve only to increase the weight of government. It will increase the burden and increase the numbers of bureaucrats, and it will create another tier of authority. The last state of those who think that they are having their problems of over-government solved will be worse than the first. It is here at Westminster that we must solve the problems of the day and reduce the burden of government and
taxation to which people so greatly object.
I pay tribute to the ingenuity of the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian and those who advised him in the way that the amendment is drawn so as to bring it within the rules of order. It would, however, make possible only a theoretical reduction of taxation and government in Scotland. If it were carried to its logical conclusion we might find that people who were working in England were hastening to reside in Scotland because the taxation there was lower. Of course, in reality it would not be lower, because the mere weight of increased bureaucracy would ensure that it was not. Theoretically, it could possibly be lower and that would lead to the ridiculous result—ridiculous in the minds of many Labour Members—of people fleeing England to pay lower taxes in Scotland.

I can assure my hon. and learned Friend that it would not be necessary to flee England because under the relevant schedule, in Amendment No. 544 upon which this all depends, the liability to tax is based upon residence in Scotland as reported in the electoral register. Therefore, one could say "I am sorry. For the purposes of this year I am resident where I have my home. For the purposes of next year I shall be resident in Scotland where I also have a home." I have a home there, too, and I am on both electoral registers. I therefore do not have to flee.

My hon. and learned Friend has expressed a very personal point of view. I am sure that very many of us would think that it would be a great advantage in the circumstances to have homes on both sides of the border.
However, the truth is that in the amendment there is a possibility—which makes a nonsense of it—that in England and in Scotland different rates of taxation should or might prevail, so as to enable persons on one side of the border or the other to resolve some of their tax problems by hastening to reside on that side of the border where taxes were lower. That is one of the logical difficulties.
It is not, however, to that difficulty that I pin my objection to the amendment. I pin my objection to it on the ground that
it gives teeth to a measure which has in it the potential to break up the United Kingdom. It is to defend the unity of the United Kingdom that I have conceived it to be my duty to take part in these debates on the Bill and the Bill that preceded it.
For those reasons, I oppose the amendment.

The hon. and learned Member for Solihull (Mr. Grieve) has at least put his finger on the problem to which we should be addressing ourselves tonight. I think that we are facing the possible break-up of the United Kingdom. It is a great likelihood. The question is whether the passing of the Bill or the failure to pass the Bill hinders, prevents, or makes more likely such a break.
However, I think that the beginning of wisdom in this matter is to understand that that is the measure of the implications with which we are dealing in the Bill. I have not been convinced that the Government Front Bench have ever taken on board those implications. I have not been convinced that the majority of the Conservative Party has done so. I am convinced that increasing numbers of people in the Labour movement in Scotland are beginning to understand these implications. That is what we are facing.
Therefore, when we look at this question, which I regard as one of the two crucial questions of the whole issue, we look at it from this point of view: does this assist us in the situation in which we have placed ourselves, facing the possible break-up, through accident, of the United Kingdom?
On this point I think that there are two things that are crucial, of which this is one. The first is the question of the referendum. I argued the case for a referendum on a two-question basis—on the ground that the passing of the Bill would solve nothing of the real problem with which we are dealing, but nor would a referendum based on a single question solve anything, because it would not have answered its own question. It would not have decided the question whether we wanted only an Assembly. It would have left the question open for the immediate use of the Assembly to crack into independence. Therefore, it seems essential to engage in the politics of the thing by
having thrashed out in Scotland the issue of independence.
I say further that if the Scottish people said "Yes" to independence, I would accept that. I would accept it infinitely more willingly than the prospect we are facing, which is of creating an Assembly without first dealing with the question of an immediate consequence of a move towards independence and then a crackup, accidentally, through acrimony and conflict, into a break-up of the United Kingdom.
Will the hon. Gentleman give way?

Not now.
That was one crucial issue. The second crucial issue was the question of responsibility of the Assembly, because without its becoming a responsible Assembly the creation of the situation I am describing becomes infinitely more likely. There would be an irresponsible Assembly—by which I mean financially irresponsible—in which the pressure would be permanently on for more moneys from London and in which the accusation would be made permanently that everything that was not achieved in Scotland was due to the meanness of the Government in London. This cannot be avoided unless we can make the Assembly responsible.
It is easy to see the scenario that we would have. Let us envisage that a new school is wanted in my area, where I was an Assemblyman. At the present time, if I were a councillor or a Member of Parliament, I would have to face up to my responsibilities on the question that no new school has been built. I cannot say that someone else is responsible for financing it. I have to say that my Government are responsible for failing to put in the moneys for the school. I have to defend the position, if necessary, but I cannot dodge the issue.
If I am a local councillor, I cannot dodge the fact that I am responsible for the failure to build the new school, because the local councillor is responsible for the level of rates. The rates and the Treasury are the direct responsibility of the councillor and the Member of Parliament. They cannot avoid this responsibility. But if I am an Assemblyman nothing can be easier for me. It is not the fault of the Assembly that the school has not been built. It is the fault of the
Government in London for failing to give a big enough block grant. As an Assemblyman, I would probably lead the campaign, and every other Assemblyman would do the same in his own area.
The demands that will be made in such an Assembly will be and must be insatiable, because there is nothing to stop the demands being made and there is everything to stop them from being satisfied. We shall therefore literally create an irresponsible Assembly.
This has not been an easy period for me as I have seen the errors being made in relation to the Bill and the politics around it. It has been difficult for me to make my decision as to the best thing for me to recommend. I have argued time and time again that all constitutions are flawed. The reason why we can accept a flawed constitution is that there is a general will in the community to accept it and to find a means of working it, despite the flaws. But there are some flaws which of themselves can prevent a constitution from operating. I accept this. I have argued frequently with the right hon. Member for Down, South (Mr. Powell) on this point. In discussion after discussion on the Bill I have tended to follow him, and my main defence has been to say "Yes" to the West Lothian question and to say "Yes" on the question of that central flaw. That position can be tolerated if the will is there to find a method of making the constitution work, with all its imperfections.
I am not sure, however, that this is the case on the question of taxation. I believe that here the flaw is such a massive one that it could crack the Assembly into independence, precisely because it creates a continuous and literally insatiable demand in the Assembly.
My hon. Friend the Member for Edinburgh, Central (Mr. Cook) referred to the comment of my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian (Mr. Mackintosh) that without tax-raising powers the situation is not tolerable. As my hon. Friend the Member for Edinburgh, Central put it, my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian must face up to the consequences of this situation.
I may also have to face the consequences, having argued the case for the Assembly—and sometimes having
been the only Labour Back Bencher to do so—that the clause has a massive flaw. I liken it to my consideration of the absence of the second question in the referendum. I do not know whether I can advise Scottish people to take the risk of going into an Assembly if we do not first settle this question.
It is for this reason that I must support the amendment. It is not that I do not think that it is flawed. Indeed, my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian will accept this. The amendment is there because we do not believe that it is impossible to find a method giving the Assembly tax-raising powers. To the extent that the amendment is inadequate, the Government, if it is passed, will have to take it away and come back with a better one. I believe, however, that without such an amendment we should be creating an enormous danger and an enormous risk for our future.
That is what is being said in the amendment. I am sure that my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian would agree. What is the situation? It is not because we wish to see necessarily a massive fluctuation in taxation.
9.45 p.m.
The argument of the right hon. Member for Down, South was circular, because he referred to the relationship between legislation being revenue-involved and expenditure-involved, one an end point of the other. That is true in any modern democracy. The right hon. Gentleman said the problem was because we would be giving not devolution but only partial devolution. He put forward a thesis of all or none with no medium position. But I believe that the Scottish and Welsh people, like the rest of the United Kingdom, want general parity of conditions throughout Britain.
It would be intolerable to Scottish people if through devolution they were to have a lower level of health benefits, pensions and social security. We therefore say "Yes" to partial devolution. We do not want the kind of devolution that will make one section of our community poorer than another in respect of these services in the same way as Scottish workers will fight for parity with the English in wages, although now
in so many cases English workers are fighting for parity with Scottish wages.
What I am saying is that we can have partial devolution with regard to the services largely administered by local government and the aspects of our life where there is a Scottish tradition and a Scottish form of doing it—for example, law and education. It is a very different thing, however, to have the kind of devolution which would be involved in the kind of taxation shift that would make a major difference and so create a tax haven.
The problem we are facing is how we deal with those problems so that the Scottish people cannot be placed in a position of saying The reason why we are being deprived of X is that the London Government is not doing it". I as an Assemblyman, for example, would have to face up to my responsibility and say "Yes, you can have that new school if you are prepared to pay X amount more in taxation". Despite the difficulty we have of discussing variations in the level of taxation, because of the form of the amendment, it is that problem with which we are dealing.
The problem is that any fluctuation and variation will be minute, but it has to be at the point at which we say "If there is anything more you want, we have to finance that extra amount above the general parity".
In Sicily, where there is regional government—but then there is regional government throughout Italy, and that makes it infinitely easier—there is not a polarised situation of one-to-one.
It was not always so.

It was not always so. There has been that situation in Sicily since 1947. But if one takes a tour on the Autostrada del Sol from the north of Italy right down to the toe, between Messina and Palermo, one pays to use the autostradas. But one does not pay on the other autostradas in Sicily—for example, from Palermo to Catania. One was built by the Italian Government as part of their national network but the others were built on the initiative of the Sicilian regional government, which had to pay for them by raising extra taxation.
That is the kind of thing which may be open to the people of Scotland. That is what we are talking about. I plead with
people to understand that what we are facing here is not the present time or this Bill but rather the creation of future conditions under which the Assembly will not of itself ruin the unity of the United Kingdom. I hope that it will be able to work. I hope that the time will be given to allow it to work and prove itself or otherwise. There are no Medes or Persians in politics.
Therefore, a newly created Assembly must itself have the responsibility of getting those extra things which it believes Scotland desires. If the Assembly is to be responsible, it cannot be continually under the kind of pressures which the SNP would be imposing continuously and correctly because it wants to crack up the United Kingdom and which other irresponsible Members of the Assembly would be forced into following. That is the argument for this amendment, and I plead with the Committee to pass it.

The hon. Member for Renfrewshire, West (Mr. Buchan) pointed to the financial dilemma of devolution and asked us to support the amendment, but even the hon. Gentleman does not claim that it will immediately resolve the dilemma. All he is saying is that it may go some way to create conditions in which, at some uncertain time in the future, the dilemma may be resolved. I am sorry to say that, having lived with this subject for some years, I think that this is an insoluble dilemma.
I wonder whether those who enthusiastically support devolution have ever asked themselves whether Scotland will be financially better off under devolution than under a system which has prevailed since the Union, with the House of Commons voting such money as will enable Scotland to keep pegging roughly level with the rest of the United Kingdom. We undertake that job in this House through estimates, through the rate support grant, which we debated before Christmas, and through specific help of one kind and another. We take that action on behalf of United Kingdom taxpayers in general—and I must emphasise that it is the taxpayers of England in particular because that is the greatest source of wealth in the United Kingdom. We undertake that task without complaining. We do it because we know that Scotland needs our help.
The question that arises is whether under any financial arrangements for devolution Scotland will be any better off. The Kilbrandon Commission spent many meetings discussing this very question. One reason why I parted company from the rest of the Kilbrandon Commission and decided that neither executive nor legislative devolution would get us off this book was that I did not think any of our studies or proposals or any solutions that were put before us would enable Scotland to have a better system than the present one to be devised for helping the people of Scotland.

Will the right hon. and learned Gentleman address his mind to the question posed by my hon. Friend the Member for Renfrewshire, West (Mr. Buchan)? We recognise how much more money per head is being made available in Scotland. However, over many years this has never been recognised and even yet in Scotland it has not been recognised. What will be the situation when the Assembly is asked to produce an extra number of schools, houses or social workers, and when the Assembly says "We cannot give you those because the Treasury in England will not provide the money"? How will the unity of the United Kingdom remain as it is unless we provide the Assembly with the power to raise finance, so that it can say to the people in Scotland "If you want a faster rate of progress than you have at present, you will have to pay for it"? That is the question that must be answered.

I am grateful for that intervention because it enables me to make the point that a Scottish Assembly will not be able to raise enough finance—certainly not as much as we now provide. Once the financial integration of the United Kingdom economy is modified in the way the Bill seeks, I do not see the House of Commons voting enough finance to make up what we now provide.
I shall follow up what the hon. Gentleman has said, because it fits in with what I was about to say. Scotland's needs per head are even greater than those of England. This is the result of simple geographical factors of two kinds. First, there is the long haul—the fact that Scotland is one of the most distant countries of Europe. Second, there are the internal geographical reasons. Within Scotland com-
munities live longer distances apart than they do in any other part of the United Kingdom. Therefore, in order to provide the same standard of living, the same standard of services, and so on, Scotland's needs are greater than those certainly of England and Wales and, I should have thought, of Northern Ireland, too.
Let us look now at the other side of the account—Scotland's capacity to pay to meet those greater needs. Alas, Scotland's capacity to pay is less. Her resources are smaller. She was the pioneer of the Industrial Revolution, but by 1914 Scotland had worked herself out of all the easily accessible coking coal, so vital for steel production and other things, and had worked herself out of all her native iron ore. Her heavy industries—coal, steel and shipbuilding—have declined. All of these would have helped the national output per head in Scotland to be of the kind necessary to meet Scotland's greater needs.
With Scotland's greater needs and at the same time smaller resources, what do we find is the outcome? In our first debate today, the hon. Member for West Lothian (Mr. Dalyell) produced one interesting set of figures, and my right hon. Friend the Member for Crosby (Mr. Page) produced another. I have been doing a little simple arithmetic since those two speeches were made. What it comes to is this. Public expenditure per head in Scotland in 1975–76, the last year for which figures are available, was 22 per cent. higher than public expenditure per head in England, while, on the other hand—I hope that the hon. Member for Aberdeen, North (Mr. Hughes) will pay attention to this—Scottish taxes in the latest year for which figures are available—the figures were given by my right hon. Friend the Member for Crosby—produced 11 per cent. less per head than did taxes in England.
Here lies the dilemma which a devolved Scottish Government and legislature would have to face—that Scotland needs more and can find less.
rose—

I ask the hon. Gentleman to allow me to pursue the matter for a moment, since I am trying to present an ordered argument to the Committee. I shall give way a little later.
For the reason which I have given, we in the House of Commons, year after year, have to vote proportionately more per head for Scotland than for England—millions of pounds' worth. We do it with only small complaint and, as hon. Members may have understood from yesterday's debate on the Public Accounts Committee, with only the minimum amount of control.

I am much obliged to the right hon. and learned Gentleman for giving way. I agree wholeheartedly with the analysis which he has made, which gives an excellent outline of the present Scottish difficulty. But he has left out oil. I do not believe that Scotland has any right to make the claims which she makes in respect of oil, but, if there were a completely separate Scotland, in all equity the rest of the United Kingdom would have to make available to Scotland the oil which is off her shores. There would have to be an agreement.
Does not the right hon. and learned Gentleman accept that there is a possibility that Scotland could use that oil in order to re-equip her industries and revitalise her economy in order to get on a par with the rest of the United Kingdom? He has left out that bit of the argument, and I should like to hear his views about it since that would complete his otherwise entirely accurate picture.

This will add to my speech in a way that I had not intended, but I am happy to do so.
Let there be no muddled thinking about the oil. The revenues from it will be needed partly to repay the enormous debts incurred for the rest of the world in recent years. That is the first call upon the oil revenues, and it is a United Kingdom call upon them.
Secondly, when we are thinking of the oil, we must think not only of the location of the oil, some of it in the same latitude as Scotland; we should also think of where the capital and the risk taking, not only in money but in lives, has come. That capital and risk taking has not all come from Scotland.
Very little.

My hon. and learned Friend the Member for Kinross and West
Perthshire (Mr. Fairbairn), who represents a Scottish constituency, says "Very little". He may be right, and we should bear that in mind.
But there is some consolation. Some of the oil terminals for oil which is within the Scottish latitude are already bringing large quantities of revenue to the Aberdeenshire coast. I remember a former hon. Member saying to me that when he was a Member his constituents were poor but happy and now they are rich and "as miserable as hell". They are getting some money from the work created at the terminals and through manning the offshore stations. But to say that this is to be the solution of what I have described as the Scottish financial dilemma would be not only fallacious for the reason that I have given but also short-sighted, because it is an accepted fact that the oil may last only 30 years, and that is a shorter time than I have been in the House. Let us by all means bear oil in mind, but do not let the misguided, charming people who represent the Scottish National Party run away with the idea that that will solve the Scottish financial dilemma.
However, the more relevant question is whether the amendment moved by the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian (Mr. Mackintosh) will do it. The right hon. Member for Down, South (Mr. Powell) described the amendment as "a valiant effort But I do not think that it will do it. I think that the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian has created a fiscal and administrative nightmare with the amendment.
Let me deal with it seriatim. First, there is the personal income tax. Presumably that excludes companies' income tax. But the personal income tax levied upon Scottish residents is to go to a Scottish Executive. However, we find that the Scottish Assembly may reduce the rates at which this income tax is levied but that it must not increase them. The object of the exercise presumably is to turn Scotland into a tax haven.

I am surprised that the right hon. and learned Gentleman raises this point. Was he not here when it was discovered that the word "increase" had to be removed to bring the amendment within the rules of order? Originally, it was "increase or decrease".
This is the object of the exercise. But the Chair kindly pointed out that "increase" was out of order. The object is to allow the Scottish Assembly to vary it within certain areas. I thought that the right hon. and learned Gentleman realised that.

I am grateful to the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian. I was present for most of the discussion on the amendment. It may be that my attention was momentarily distracted, possibly by myself.
So we should read "vary" for "reduce". Let us say that the Scottish Assembly varies the rates. Very well. If it reduces them, it turns Scotland into a tax haven for English taxpayers, and there will be a great influx from across the border. Splendid. But if the Assembly finds that it does not get enough money to meet the greatly increased Scottish needs, the position is the other way round. Then England becomes a tax haven, for the first time in history. I wonder whether the hon. Gentleman really thinks that that would go towards a solution of the financial dilemma for Scotland. I doubt it.
Let us take the proceeds of the assigned excise taxes levied in Scotland—on tobacco, alcohol, betting and gaming, and hydrocarbon oils. When a Scotsman drinks a bottle of whisky, not the whole of the tax on it will go to the Scottish Assembly, only half. If that is to pay for the extra cost of separate administration, it seems to me to be a very large chunk of the tax on a bottle of whisky to allocate for such a purpose. If the hon. Gentleman will turn to one of the appendices to the Kilbrandon Report, he will find that those of my colleagues, with all of whom I disagreed on these matters, who did go seriously into the question of which taxes could be allocated for Scottish purposes did not go for 50 per cent.—they went for the whole bottle. I should be interested to know why the hon. Gentleman has gone for only 50 per cent. I should have thought that he would go for at least 90 per cent., allowing a generous proportion of 10 per cent., perhaps two double Scotches, for administrative purposes.

The object was to raise enough money to cover the equivalent
of the block grant. The other moneys would pay for what were referred to in the Government of Ireland Act as imperial purposes—defence, foreign affairs, and so on. It was an attempt to raise enough money without personal income tax to raise the equivalent of a block grant which would then be disposable by the Assembly.

Noble sentiments indeed, but that does not display any confidence in the financial excellence and success of the Scottish Executive, because we read on that if the receipts of personal income tax and the half share of the assigned excise taxes are not enough, there is to be an equalisation payment from the Treasury. So we are back to square one—a block grant. The only difference is that, instead of there being a once-and-for-all annual effort, working out exactly how much Scotland needs for its services, there is to be this very complicated series of calculations, in the course of which there will be an estimate of the Scottish proportion of public expenditure, including the very matters that the hon. Gentleman has mentioned—defence, foreign affairs, and, no doubt, overseas aid and all kinds of other things. In this connection, I ask him whether we are to assume that there is to be some form of continuation of rate support grant to local authorities in Scotland. The hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian nods. Well, that is that one.
We know that there are to be further rates for local authorities to raise. We know that the Scottish Office will continue to lay Estimates before the House in respect of non-devolved matters affecting Scotland. The hon. Member has not moved other amendments to the Bill which would deal with the question of what is to happen to the block grant, which remains in the Bill. There would be an overlapping of his proposals with those of the Government.
It seems that, instead of the smooth-working, felicitous way in which we vote hundreds of millions of pounds for the benefit of Scotland from the general body of taxpayers of the United Kingdom—instead of these excellent arrangements which have served Scotland so generously and effectively—we are to have awful wrangles in the House of Commons which we do not now have. We shall have
conflict, which is minimised at the moment.
I am sorry to say that the worm might turn and we may find that there is an attitude of some parsimony on the part of English Members and English taxpayers which, in their generosity they do not display under the present system. For these reasons, I hope that the valiant efforts of the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian will not be supported by the Committee. I hope, too, that the Government will bear in mind the things said in this debate and in the earlier one and take the Bill away, realising that from the financial point of view, which matters to the Scots, devolution will be a disaster.

On a point of order, Mr. Godman Irvine. Perhaps I am the last person to make any complaint—and I am not complaining—but I think the Com-
mittee should realise that we are in something of a situation. In roughly 40 minutes' time the guillotine will fall on clauses up to Clause 60. There are many vital matters which will be undiscussed. My hon. Friend the Minister of State will say that this is the responsibility of the House of Commons, and I am not blaming the Government for this, because, perhaps, all of us have some responsibility. My point is simple. In these unique circumstances could there not be a discussion through the usual channels to see how the problem may be alleviated?

speech.speakername: The Second Deputy Chairman (Mr. Bryant Godman Irvine)
speech.p: No doubt the hon. Member's observations have been heard by the usual channels, who will take such steps as they feel desirable.

This is one of the most important subjects with which we have had to deal on this Bill. The Committee has spent considerably longer on less important matters. There are three elements in the amendment which, I agree with my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian (Mr. Mackintosh), are essential to the proper working of the Assembly. I hope that the amendment will be passed so as to give the Government the opportunity to table their considered views on how best to tackle the objectives, given the will of the Committee in this matter.
I am sure that my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian would agree that there are difficulties about some aspects of his proposals. For example, if the nominal imputed income from these taxes rises or falls above or below the 90 per cent. of imputed expenditure, the Assembly could suddenly become or cease to become eligible for equalisation grants. These are matters of detail—

Does not my hon. Friend realise that that type of weakness is built into any system which seeks to have equalisation on the basis of need and that there is no escape from it? That is one of the fundamental weaknesses of trying to have some revenue powers for the Assembly, which have foxed Ministers for a long time.

There are difficulties in any equalisation formula. I agree that it is a problem that must be dealt with.
There are three broad areas of consideration which have led to arguments for and against taxation powers for the Assembly. There are economic, administrative and political arguments. The economic arguments have been mistaken by those who argue that it is essential to maintain the central management of the United Kingdom economy. That is an important argument, but it is like arguing that because one wants to keep a motor car in one piece one must bolt the wheel axles on to the chassis. The one sure thing is that, if one does that, the car will shake itself to bits. If one says "But car suspensions are awkward, expensive things to design", then, alas,
that is so, but some flexibility in the economic relationships between the different parts of the United Kingdom is an essential part of maintaining the economic integrity of the United Kingdom.
Let us take, for example, the firemen's dispute. How will such a dispute be handled when there is a Scottish Assembly? Under the Bill as it stands, it would be open to the Assembly to settle with the Firemen. Given the political pressures, given that we have very little of the present financial year to run, and given the political problems that there might be in Scotland, it is not inconceivable that the Assembly would settle with the firemen for a substantial increase, with the expectation that that settlement would automatically spread to the rest of the United Kingdom and would not be met by a reduction in the pay of other public service workers in Scotland.
How would Clause 40 affect that argument?

It was defeated by the hon. and learned Gentleman and his hon. Friends.
To meet the problem of the rigidity of public sector pay negotiations, the Government wished to exclude such negotiations from the powers of the Assembly in their previous Bill, giving the Secretary of State a veto. That has been removed from the Bill. The Committee has defeated the statutory application of incomes policy to Scotland in the Bill. Now we face the situation whereby almost automatically the Assembly will be able to dictate the incomes policy of the United Kingdom.
The only way in which the Government can protect themselves against that perhaps automatic inflationary pressure from public sector pay claims in Scotland is to have a system by which the payment of those public sector wages can be kept within Scotland. For better or worse, and however the Assembly cares to juggle it, that can only be by tax powers. If it is left to adjustments in other parts of public sector pay, the political pressures will inevitably be too hard to contain within Scotland and they will burst out into the rest of the United Kingdom.

But how would the
amendment achieve the end that my hon. Friend seeks? My hon. Friend was saying that if firemen were paid more in Scotland there would be a likelihood that a higher settlement would be agreed in England. Surely that is just as likely to happen if the amendment is passed as if it is not. The Scottish Assembly would prefer that the English firemen should be paid more, so that the relationship between the expenditure on the two sides of the border should remain the same. England might say that the cost of that increase in Scotland should be borne on extra Scottish taxation. But the realities of politics would surely dictate that in many circumstances English firemen's wages were settled at the same high level as they had been led to by a Scottish settlement.

The argument is very difficult, whether the increase is met by the reduction of other public servants' pay in Scotland, which is what the Government are relying on at present, or by increased taxation in Scotland. That is still difficult, but perhaps slightly less difficult than reducing the pay of, say, primary school teachers in Scotland.
That is the quandary to which the Government are now subjecting the Assembly. It is an unrealistic political quandary into which to put the Assembly. My belief is that the inevitable result will be that Westminster will be forced into giving the Assembly tax powers simply to contain the political and economic pressures within Scotland.
On the administrative front, we are told that it will cost another £2,000 million to have a different rate of income tax in Scotland. That is on the assumption that the present income tax system will survive. Like other hon. Members who have spoken, I doubt whether it will. The Inland Revenue had a proposal for computerisation of PAYE in the late 1960s. It was a plan involving the creation of a number of computer centres throughout the United Kingdom, each employing 5,000 tax officers. It was not to be fully implemented before 1985. At that time I was a Minister, and I pointed out that this was a totally unrealistic tax plan and that administration and methods would change so much that it would not get beyond 1970 before it collapsed. That,
in fact, occurred. The system was abandoned by the Conservative Government after they came to office in 1970.
We shall get enormous changes in the tax system. I believe that self-assessment is a strong contender and that some form of negative income tax is likely to be introduced. In the changed pattern of income tax, there is bound to be the important consideration that its administration should be simplified and adapted to the completely different pattern of clerical procedures that are part of the expansion of computerisation by employers and by Government Departments. The basic restructuring of the system will come under pressure from the impending breakdown of the present system. The Inland Revenue will not admit that the system is breaking down. We just get longer and longer delays. But sooner or later changes will have to be made.
It is arguable that we should seek to precipitate this process by saying that for political reasons the Scottish Assembly must have different tax powers. If we do this for the Assembly, we should also do it for the highest level of local authorities in England and for whatever is appropriate in Wales. If we change the basis of income taxation in England and the basis of taxation for the Scottish Assembly, the difficulties will be removed.
We cannot put that provision into the Bill because we are stuck with the present income tax system for the time being. However, I hope that we will vote for the amendment as a warning flag to the Government that the matter must be dealt with urgently.
We could give the Assembly powers to vary the rates of a number of taxes and leave it to the Assembly to propose the means by which it could do so. That puts the Assembly into the position of feeling the political pressures—I instance the current case of the firemen's claim, but there will be many other equally urgent claims upon the Assembly. Under these political pressures and responsibilities, the Assembly must propose administrative means for fulfilling its objectives. Let it open negotiations with the Government at Westminster and discussions with the House of Commons to arrive at a pattern of taxation that is better for the United Kingdom as a whole.

Does my hon. Friend realise that what he has just suggested is infinitely simpler than what is suggested in the amendment? The objective could be achieved for the Scottish Assembly if it were given power to vary the rate of certain taxes with the loss to the Revenue being deducted from the block grant or the profits being added to the block grant. This could still be subjected to endless objections. Never-the less, it is simpler than what is proposed in the amendment.

I agree entirely but the point here is the principle. If we do not vote for the amendment in principle, there will be no other opportunity in the Bill to indicate the wish of the House to have tax powers for the Scottish Assembly. The question for the House is not whether we have a Scottish Assembly but whether, if we have such an Assembly, it should have tax powers. That is the simple principle that we are debating.

is my hon. Friend suggesting a situation in which taxes could be varied so that hon. Members would have to go to their constituents and say that for the sake of this great devolution scheme their petrol will be taxed higher than that in England and they will have to pay more for their whisky? We should be subjected to the most appalling ribald comment.

The pattern of expenditure and taxation in Scotland will adjust in different ways from the pattern in England. I argue that the pattern is likely to change even between different parts of England and Wales. I know that my hon. Friend is a good regionalist and would prefer regional devolution within Scotland as well as within England, and I cannot understand why he does not treat the Assembly as a pioneering development of that wider devolution which he quite properly seeks.
For the sake of containing the economic unity, a viable tax administration and a political future for the unity of the United Kingdom, I hope that the amendment will be carried.

We are not debating the establishment of a federal system. If we were, we would be involved with a written constitution
which would act as a cushion between the two sides of the argument—the federal Parliament and the Parliament of the various States involved. A written constitution would provide neutral ground.
The Bill is doomed to failure since the concept of devolution that we are debating is likely to lead to chaos or disaster because of the arguments which will arise from such an act. We are debating a concept which, as far as I know, has never existed before. It is all the more important, therefore, to try to provide means whereby there will be the minimum amount of argument between this Parliament and the Scottish Assembly.
Probably the most contentious arguments between this Parliament and the Assembly will be over the financing of matters devolved to the Assembly. The only hope of reducing those arguments is to provide the Assembly with power to raise finance itself. That would achieve the objective of the amendment of forcing responsibility upon the Assembly. If it does not have that power, it will act irresponsibly. A cushion is needed, and that can be provided only by forcing responsibility on the Assembly through giving it the power to raise finance.
Secondly, there is the important point that he who pays the piper calls the tune. I do not believe that the Scottish people will accept that the Assembly, without the power to raise finance, will have the control over the course of events in Scotland that presumably they will wish it to have.
10.30 p.m.
For example, if the Scottish Assembly were to decide to introduce a system of education—whether primary or secondary does not matter—different from that in England and such a system required considerable extra capital resources to finance it, the English Parliament and Government would be faced with a dilemma. The Scottish Assembly would, in effect, come to the Westminster Government and say "We have proposed this excellent new system of education, but it will cost a lot of extra money. May we have that extra money in our block grant?"
It might be that the Westminster Government would say "Yes", but it seems more likely that they would say "No", for one of two reasons: first, because they would not have the money—that
would be the most likely reason—or, secondly, because they disagreed with the proposed system of education to be introduced in Scotland. Either way, the Scottish Assembly would be likely to suggest that, over what should be a devolved matter, the Westminster Parliament was still exercising indirect control. Therefore, if there is to be any hope for the smooth introduction of a devolved system, it is important that the Assembly should have the power to raise finance.
Finally, I should like to refer to the power of local authorities to raise money by the rating system. I am opposed to the rating system in the sense that it is an inefficient form of raising money for local government. Its inefficiency is proved by the fact that over 50 per cent. of local government expenditure is now provided by the block grant from Westminster. Whilst it is easy to say that, it is not so easy to suggest an alternative, for one simple reason. The local authority unit, be it in England or in Scotland, is so small that any other means whereby it could raise finance would considerably increase the overhead administrative costs. But that point would not hold good if a system of raising finance were to be introduced in an area the size of Scotland, Wales, England or—I do not like to think of such a possibility—the regions in England.
I do not suggest that the proposal outlined in the amendment is perfect, but I believe that it is within the bounds of possibility to introduce a system of raising finance within an area the size of Scotland which would enable the Scottish Assembly to act responsibly. I do not believe that it will be able to act responsibly if the Bill is passed as drafted.

First, one must point out the impossible position that we are in because of the guillotine. We have spent almost the whole day discussing an unstarred, amended amendment, and the result is that we have had only one day to discuss the crucial question of financing the Assembly. We shall not be able to discuss 17 of the 18 clauses. We shall not have a discussion on the Question "That the clause stand part of the Bill", nor shall we look at the schedule. This is intolerable since this is an important part of the Bill.
The Minister may say that we have only ourselves to blame for this situation because we have talked for so long, but every speech has been constructive. There has not been a filibuster. Admittedly, hon. Members have been confused about a confusing subject, but they have raised matters which worry them. The debate has been notable for the real unhappiness that hon. Members on all sides feel about the Bill.
One of the views expressed was that of the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian (Mr. Mackintosh), who said that the financing of the Assembly was unsatisfactory. He said that it will not work, it does not make sense and, therefore, we must try some other form of revenue raising. Other hon. Members say that there must be an alternative form of revenue raising that must work, but they do not know what it is.
All hon. Members who spoke in favour of the amendment said "We do not like the amendment. We do not think that it makes sense. We do not think that it will work. It is costly and bureaucratic, but we shall vote for it because we must find a form of alternative revenue raising."

There is another alternative which might commend itself to my hon. Friend the Member for Glasgow, Cathcart (Mr. Taylor) and to the Committee. Why could not the Assembly have no grant and why not leave the responsibility of raising the whole of the revenue with Chancellor Crawford of Edinburgh, and then let the Scottish people vote in the referendum?

That is the logic to which one is drawn. There is a case for going a long way, there is a case for going not very far at all, but there is precious little argument for this half-way house.
What are the options? The hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian said that the present proposals for financing the Assembly are wrong and that they will create confusion and frustration because we are creating an Assembly with powers. But we are giving it the powers of a hospital board. It will be able to spend money allocated to it by Westminster but not to raise money, and this will create conflict. Despite all the wise words about how the
system will work, the Leader of the House, who represents a Welsh constituency, must be aware that the same applies to Wales.
In the last 18 months, because of the serious economic situation, local authorities have been forced to cut down on home helps, to close residential homes and to increase local authority rates. Does the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian honestly envisage that if we had this type of Assembly Westminster would say "You must cut down on everything because we are short of money"? Does he imagine that the Assembly would then say that it would voluntarily cut down the number of home helps, close residential homes and do all the other nasty things? Inevitably this would be a recipe for conflict. It certainly would have been last year, and it will be in future years.
There is another reason why the proposals in the Bill are unacceptable. If there is a block grant, it will be an annual occasion for identifying the extra which Scotland gets as a result of its needs. At present, because of special problems concerned with remoteness, unemployment and so on, Scotland gets a lot more than its share on the basis of population from the United Kingdom Treasury. There has been much comment about the amounts involved. The hon. Member for Perth and East Perthshire (Mr. Crawford) said that we should leave out of consideration the question of defence. If, however, we restrict ourselves only to devolved subjects, we find, from reading Hansard of 2nd December last, that Scotland gets £360 per head of the population, Wales gets £320 and England gets £280. On devolved subjects, therefore, Scotland gets 25 to 30 per cent. more, not as a bonus but because of its special problems.
But will it be quite so easy if every year we present to the House of Commons a set of figures for the block grant which require hon. Members such as the hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Heffer), whose constituency has a high level of unemployment, to agree to Scotland getting 25 or 30 per cent. more? We shall face the kind of problems which we have hitherto avoided.
Another reason why the system will not work is that there could be a form of
indirect taxation whereby the Assembly, wanting more money and unable to get it from Westminster, would give less to the local authorities, which in turn would have to impose sky-high rates to make up the difference.
There is broad agreement in Scotland that the Government's proposals will not work, but what do we do? Those who support the amendment say that there must be some form of revenue-raising power. This is not a new problem. The Government have studied it, and in that context I hope that hon. Members who have taken an interest in the matter will sttudy the White Paper "Devolution: Financing the Devolved Services". The Government have been through all this. They have concluded that to have a separate rate of income tax as proposed by the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian would involve enormous cost. Twenty per cent. of the yield would be taken up by administration. There will be enormous problems on the question of residence. The hon. Member proposes solutions, and I shall come to them, but there is no doubt that this will be a major problem.
It might be suggested that Scotland should raise all its own taxes. But with only partial devolution, and with Scotland being only a part of the United Kingdom, that would not work. There is also the difficulty of having separate rates of tax in a highly integrated economy.
The hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian has argued for a half-way house which, he must accept, is complete nonsense. He is suggesting not tax-raising powers but a complex, costly and "phoney" accountancy exercise. He is suggesting a block grant written up in a different way, a block grant with a mink coat which will cost about £7 million in administration. He suggests taking some of the income tax proceeds from Scotland and adding to them the proceeds from duty on drink and gambling. He then suggests considering what Scotland would have got under the block grant on the basis of the same percentage of expenditure as we get now. If there were a difference, an equalisation payment would be made, and the hon. Member allows for a variation of 10 per cent.
This all reminds me of what we used to do when I worked in the Clyde shipyards when we calculated the apprentices'
piecework rate. We used to calculate how many feet of welding had been done, add an award bonus, even though the award had been phased out, and then add the differentials, and if the result was different from 3s. 7½d. an hour we used to add to or subtract from the amount to make it 3s. 7½d. an hour. This involved a great deal of work. It gave me a job. But, frankly, what the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian is proposing is exactly the same thing. He is not employing me in the shipyards, but he wants to employ 2,000 extra civil servants and spend £7 million in doing so.

Will the hon. Gentleman realise that, apart from his interesting personal experiences, this method of allocating the product of certain taxes between a devolved Government and the central Government is the procedure employed by the United States, Canada, Australia and Germany, and that they all do it because it gives the devolved Government a share of revenue which is not subject to the whim of the national legislature and is not subject to all the defects of demands for accountability by the people who then would give it, which would be the central Parliament?

Being a professor, the hon. Gentleman should at least read the amendment. He talks about an assured income. What he says is that the assured income is a percentage of United Kingdom expenditure. If the Government decided to spend more money on defence, as we were glad to hear the other day, Scotland would get more. On the other hand, if we had to pay more in Common Market contributions, Scotland would get less. If this is accepted on the basis of a percentage of United Kingdom expenditure, there is no guarantee at all. What the hon. Gentleman is suggesting is not revenue raising.
Will the hon. Gentleman give way?

Certainly not. If the hon. Gentleman would reply to my letters, I might give way to him. I have sent him three letters, to which he has never replied. When he replies to my letters, I shall give way to him.
We must remember that, first of all, the proposal in the amendment is not revenue raising. Secondly, it would be
costly and bureaucratic, with the extra 2,000 civil servants. Also, it is not merely the cost in civil servants. What the hon. Member for Berwick and East Lothian must accept is that, according to the White Paper and all the Government's common sense, not only would the Government spend an extra £7 million but industry, commerce and employers would have to spend the same. The hon. Gentleman shakes his head, but he must be aware—this is in the White Paper and it is common sense—that much of the cost of raising taxes now is borne not by the Government but by industry, which does the job of tax collecting for the Government. There would be much extra cost if we had to decide whether an individual lived in Scotland or in England.
The hon. Gentleman suggested that we should allocate the separate Scottish and English income tax, if there is a difference, not on the basis of residence but according to which electoral roll contains an individual's name. How does one get on to an electoral roll? One has to reside at a certain place on a certain day. Frankly, if there were differences between Scottish and English income tax, I believe that we should have the nonsense of people moving to Gretna Green or Carlisle on the day of registration.
What is proposed is a complex scheme. It is a facade of separate tax raising, which is not separate tax raising at all. Those who support the principle of the amendment have said "We know that this scheme is rubbish but we must have something. We cannot have an Assembly with no tax-raising powers."
The very valuable point made by my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Huntingdonshire (Sir D. Renton) was that there may not be an answer—this is the matter to which we have to turn our minds—whereby we can, with partial devolution to part of the United Kingdom, have separate tax-raising powers.
Unless all those who are contemplating supporting the amendment are confident that they have the answer to this enigma—for which the Government have looked for a long time but have been unable to find, after even considering separate taxation of beds in Scotland—before they support the amendment, which I have no mind to do, they should consider whether
they believe that there is an answer to this enigma. They should consider whether it is not simply a case that as we continue discussing the Bill we come more and more to the conclusion that what the Government are proposing is a recipe for conflict and disaster and a recipe for more government and worse government.

We have had a very wide-ranging debate and covered many topics, perhaps the most fascinating of which was the history given by the hon. Member for Glasgow, Cathcart (Mr. Taylor) of his activities in the shipbuilding industry—probably the most useful period of his life. But we have tackled some of the fundamental problems involved in the taxation arrangements and the expenditure arrangements for the Scottish Assembly.
I want to make some criticisms of the Amendment moved by my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian (Mr. Mackintosh). I do not want to make carping or legalistic criticisms of it, although there are many that could possibly be made. I want to go to the heart of the question.
A number of hon. Members have said that they would like to see some form of revenue-raising powers. Nearly all of them have said, as did the hon. Member for Cathcart, that they do not agree with the proposals put forward by my hon. Friend.
I intervened earlier to try to give some figures to assist my hon. Friend's argument so that it would be more clearly understood by the Committee. If the Committee were to adopt the amendment, the proceeds from personal income tax would amount to just under £1,300 million. The amount that would come from the assigned taxes—50 per cent.—would be about £266 million, and there would have to be an equalisation factor of about £330 million. The £266 million is a very notional figure, and it would be extremely difficult in practical terms to assign excise duties as they arose, because the way in which they arise at the point of collection is rather haphazard. A large amount would be collected on whisky in Scotland. The figure I have given is based on the family income survey: it is very artificial. It would be impractical to allocate the assigned excise duties on the basis that they were levied in Scotland.
How much further on are we in replacing a block grant by assigned revenues? When I pointed out the figures, my hon. Friend said that if 50 per cent. was wrong he would make it 60 per cent., but the Assembly does not have power to vary that at all. It would perhaps have to be put into the Bill. What my hon. Friend is trying to do is by one means or another to add up the amount that the block grant would arrive at and then give a marginal variation. I do not see very much difference between having the block grant covering the area of the assigned taxes and having a separate heading called assigned taxes. The real point of the amendment is that there ought to be—[HON. MEMBERS: "Turn round so that we can hear."]. It makes no difference in regard to responsibility, because it would be a notional allocation of resources to the Scottish Assembly. But the main point which I think my hon. Friend is seeking to make is that there ought to be the power to vary personal income tax.
The hon. Member for Cathcart said that the Government have looked carefully at this. Indeed we have, and the White Paper dealing with finance and devolved services is a long catalogue of the whole series of propositions and possible taxes that were considered very carefully in an attempt to find an answer to one of the difficulties about having a variation in the personal income tax rate. We looked at it from the point of view of a supplement rather than a substitute. Philosophically it is much the same thing. The Scottish Assembly might, for example, add on 2p.
The major difficulty is the way in which income tax is collected in this country, as was pointed out in the debate. Under the PAYE system it is extremely difficult to have this regional or national variation without very high cost. The cost to which my hon. Friend referred was obtained by him from the Financial Secretary to the Treasury when he put a Question to him about the cost of levying income tax on people employed in Scotland, not resident in Scotland. He received the answer that there was a staff of 2,000 costing approximately £7 million.
As the hon. Member for Inverness (Mr. Johnston) indicated, the cost on the basis of residence would be £8 million. On a slightly different basis it could be £10
million. Taking it, however, on the basis of £8 million, we have to add, as the hon. Member for Cathcart rightly said, another £8 million for the employers, because the Inland Revenue calculates that for every pound that it costs to raise tax by PAYE—and because we place burdens on employers in collecting taxes—there would be another pound to add to that, so that the cost of this variation would be £16 million.
My hon. Friend asks "What does that matter?" Since under the terms of job creation we could create 2,000 jobs, or whatever it would be, at a cost of £16 million. It is not as simple as that. One has to work out whether it is possible to have this marginal capacity to raise a few extra millions. I do not think that it would be politically possible for the Assembly to have a variation of 20p, which is what the amendment amounts to. That is taking a view which is beyond the realms of political reality. We must have a narrower band than that.
If we had an extra 2p or 3p, the extra amount collected would be a small proportion of the block grant figure of £1,800 million which is likely to arise under the block grant.
On a point of order, Mr. Godman Irvine. Would the Minister mind addressing himself to the Committee and not only to the Benches behind him?

I shall endeavour to do that. But the hon. and learned Gentleman must understand that I am trying to answer points which came from behind me. I hope that he will acquit me of discourtesy in not addressing him.
Many hon. Members have said that we should have a system of revenue raising. No one has yet come forward with a system of revenue raising which is economical and practical. My hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian has not put it forward in the amendment. I do not think that any other hon. Member who has contributed to the debate has put forward a system of revenue raising that is reasonably economical.
Of course, hon. Members may say that there may be changes in our system of collecting taxes and that we might move away from the PAYE system towards a system of self-assessment, although that has other problems which
countries which operate that system would confirm. However, we must deal with the existing taxation system in this country. I do not think that it would be right to put into the Bill general powers of taxation raising without knowing what the consequences would be—for example, the cost of collection and the implications for both the Assembly and the United Kingdom.
We believe that the best way to deal with this is on the basis of the block grant. If our system of taxation changed and if some of the difficulties were removed, no doubt the matter could be looked at again. I stress that a great deal of the costs arise because we operate the system of tax collection that we do.
In the discussions that we have had about the whole system of finance since the Scotland and Wales Bill, particularly in discussions with the Liberal Party, other suggestions were put forward. One in particular, which was interesting, was that instead of having an annual discussion with the Assembly we ought to have it over four years and perhaps fix a percentage whereby the Assembly might have, say, 11·2 per cent. or 10·8 per cent. of the total money spent on similar services in England.
That might form a basis upon which we could deal with the finances of the Assembly on other than an annual basis. That proposal came forward from the Liberal Party and I pay tribute to its members for having put forward the idea. It is one which the Government favour. We think that it has a great deal of merit in it. We believe, however, that it has to be discussed fully by the Scottish Assembly. It is a proposal which the Government will put to the Assembly once it is established.
We also believe that to try to objectify the basis on which the negotiations would be considered would also be a useful element in assessing this. Basically, however, the allocation of finance within the United Kingdom must be on the basis of need. That is recognised by my hon. Friend the Member for Berwick and East Lothian in the fact that he has placed an equalisation formula within his proposal. He referred to the systems of other countries. It is quite true of Australia and Canada. I draw attention to the situation in West Germany, where there is little in the way of independent
tax-raising elements. They are allocated shares, and so much is allocated to different taxes. But there is little that the Länder Governments can do by cutting public services to reduce the burden of taxation. Taxation rates are fixed at the federal level. It is an interesting but the least understood feature of the German system. It is difficult to compare this situation with a different one. This is the
